headline: Turkish Novelist's Case Sent Back to Court
abstract: The Turkish Justice Ministry on Sunday declined to rule on whether a criminal trial of the novelist Orhan Pamuk on a charge of insulting ''Turkishness'' should proceed.      The Justice Ministry's action sent the case back to an Istanbul court, which in December had postponed the trial, saying that it was up to the government to decide whether to proceed with the case.

headline: Apple wows investors
This Site Knows a Cold Isn't a Rock Band
abstract: HYPOCHONDRIACS of the world, rejoice: a new Web site, Healthline.com, could make it easier to identify whatever doesn't ail you.     The core mission of the Web site, which is owned by Healthline Networks, is to act as a medical search engine, finding articles on ailments and remedies from some 66,000 Web sites it has identified as providing medical content. In doing so, Healthline says it offers consumers a broader choice of information than WebMD, which is by far the most popular single medical resource online, and a more refined choice than general search engines like Google.

headline: Refugee Crisis Grows as Darfur War Crosses a Border
abstract: The chaos in Darfur, the war-ravaged region in Sudan where more than 200,000 civilians have been killed, has spread across the border into Chad, deepening one of the world's worst refugee crises.      Arab gunmen from Darfur have pushed across the desert and entered Chad, stealing cattle, burning crops and killing anyone who resists. The lawlessness has driven at least 20,000 Chadians from their homes, making them refugees in their own country.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: THE NEW GUY -- Ben S. Bernanke oversees his first Fed meeting as chairman this week. The two-day meeting begins today; a decision on interest rates is expected tomorrow. Economists predict that the Fed will again raise its benchmark overnight lending rate a quarter-point, to 4.75 percent.    ON THE BLOCK -- Bids are due tomorrow for the 12 Knight Ridder newspapers that McClatchy, which won the bidding for the chain, wants to sell.    WINDOWS IN EUROPE -- The European Commission holds a hearing on Thursday and Friday on Microsoft's compliance with a March 2004 antitrust order.    CONTRACT TALKS -- Delphi, the bankrupt auto parts maker, has said that if it does not reach agreements with its major unions on lower-cost contracts by Thursday, it will ask the bankruptcy court for permission to reject the contracts and impose new wage scales. Officials of the United Auto Workers say that could prompt a strike that could hurt Delphi and its main customer, General Motors.    THE NEXT CYCLE -- The Justice Department's new antitrust chief, Thomas O. Barnett, has until Thursday to decide whether to file a lawsuit to block the $1.7 billion purchase of Maytag by Whirlpool.    MEDICAL MERGER -- Shareholders of Boston Scientific and Guidant will vote Friday on their proposed merger.    ECONOMIC PULSE -- Reports on the economy this week will include the Conference Board's consumer confidence figures, to be released tomorrow; the final fourth-quarter revision to gross domestic product on Thursday; and February figures for factory orders, the Chicago Purchasing Managers index and personal income and spending data, all on Friday.

headline: Bombers attempt attack on Saudi oil facility
Union Is Pessimistic on a Deal To Avert a Shutdown at Delphi
abstract: Leaders of United Auto Workers union express doubt that deal with General Motors could be reached on assistance plan for Delphi Corp to buy out workers before March 31 deadline; union has threatened to strike if judge agrees to set aside labor contracts and impose sharply lower wages (M)

headline: Mittal Steel Makes Bid for a Rival
abstract: The biggest steel company in the world wants to get much bigger.     Mittal Steel, whose founder, Lakshmi Mittal, has never been bashful about his global ambitions, shocked the industry on Friday with an unsolicited $22.8 billion bid for the world's second-biggest steel company, Arcelor.

headline: U.S. opens two fronts in an effort to 'defeat' Iran
At elite French school, real revolutionaries
Nacchio seeks dismissal of indictment
Voice billed as Zawahiri's on Web site
Turk bird flu cluster raises worries
Belarus Opposition Candidate Injured in Melee With Police
abstract: Security officers in Belarus arrest Aleksandr V Kazulin, opposition candidate running against Pres Aleksandr G Lukashenko in March 19 election, setting off brawl in which he is punched and suffers bruised face and broken lip; Kazulin is released by police more than eight hours later, but not before his arrest prompts protests, more scuffles with police and dozens more detentions in Minsk, Belarus capital; Kazulin photo (M)

headline: Hamas Presses Fatah in Palestinian Vote, Surveys Say
abstract: Hamas, the militant Islamic party sworn to the destruction of Israel, won a large share of votes in the first Palestinian legislative elections in a decade, depriving the more secular Fatah party of its longstanding monopoly on power, surveys of voters leaving the polls indicated Wednesday.     While those surveys showed Fatah with a narrow lead, the vote marked the first entry of Hamas into representative Palestinian politics, a fundamental change, and its strong showing raised questions about the near-term future of any peace talks with Israel.

headline: Egypt's Valley of Kings yields a major new burial site
Paris fines perfume firms
Milosevic's son says his father was murdered
ViewPoints: Another moment of truth in Japan
World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Investors Sue Shell in U.S.
abstract: More than two dozen institutional investors have joined to sue Royal Dutch Shell in Federal District Court in New Jersey, seeking several hundred million dollars in damages in connection with a scandal in 2004 that involved inflated estimates of oil reserves. Many of the plaintiffs are European pension funds, including ABP of the Netherlands, one of the world's largest. In filing the new suit, ABP and others now intend to opt out of an earlier suit against Shell that is awaiting class-action certification in an American court, a spokesman said. The European shareholders hope that their new action will award them a larger share of damages than the earlier complaint, he added. Shell said it would vigorously defend itself against both actions.    GREGORY CROUCH (NYT)

headline: Soda Sales Fall for First Time in 20 Years
abstract: The next generation may not be the Pepsi generation -- or the Coke generation, for that matter.     For years, soda has been the quintessential American drink, considered the perfect thirst quencher, morning pick-me-up or accompaniment to lunch or dinner.

headline: Conservative wins vote in Portugal
In Mexico, a man and his 'Penguin' seek office
Iran Says It Will Resume Nuclear Fuel Research
abstract: Iran today appeared to take a harder line on the long-running dispute over its nuclear programs.

headline: 2 tiers take hold in high-wage U.S. labor
G.M. to Invest $500 Million in Michigan
abstract: General Motors will announce plans to invest $500 million to help modernize five Michigan factories; investments will not create large number of jobs; GM lost $8.6 billion in 2005 and is looking for ways to reduce costs (M)

headline: Science Blogs as a Vehicle for Upscale Ads
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on Seed Media Group, producer of print and online science publications, which is seeking to broaden its audience and appeal to advertisers with new network of blogs devoted to science and science-related subjects; network is to be made available on Web site, scienceblogs.com, that is currently operating in test mode; blog network is sign of growing interest among media companies and advertisers in using new media to sell products (Advertising column) (M)

Briefcase: Job slots follow 'snowbird' workers

abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,293 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:    MERCHANT, Christopher S., 32, Specialist, Army National Guard; Hardwick, Vt.; Third Battalion, 172nd Infantry Regiment.    YOUMANS, Joshua V., 26, Sgt., Army National Guard; Flushing, Mich.; First Battalion, 125th Infantry Regiment.

headline: China nears Australian uranium deal
Accounts
abstract: Macy's, New York, a division of Federated Department Stores, named Starcom USA, Chicago, as the first agency to handle its estimated $200 million national media planning and buying account. The assignment had previously been handled internally. Macy's spends an additional $300 million a year in local media. Starcom USA is part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Publicis Groupe.      SanDisk Corporation, Sunnyvale, Calif., selected the San Francisco office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group division of the WPP Group, to handle its account, which had been at the San Francisco office of Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas. Spending for 2006 was estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two US soldiers in Iraq (S)

headline: A Military Raid Frees 3 Hostages Held in Iraq
abstract: Acting on a tip from a detainee, a multinational military force stormed a house in western Baghdad early Thursday and rescued two Canadians and a Briton who had been held hostage by a shadowy guerrilla group for four months.      James Loney, 41, and Harmeet Singh Sooden, 32, both from Canada, and Norman Kember, 74, from Britain, were discovered bound yet unguarded, officials reported. The three were whisked to the fortified Green Zone and debriefed by the authorities, officials said, but did not address the news media.

headline: Chief of Atomic Agency Sounds Optimistic on Iran
abstract: Mohamed ElBaradei was hopeful that an agreement could be reached with Iran on its nuclear program in "the next week or so."

headline: Germans strike to fight longer workweek
A Conservative Evolves, and Leads a Canadian Race
abstract: ''God bless all of you, God bless Canada!'' is the way Stephen Harper finishes every campaign stump speech as he appears to be heading toward a landslide victory to become prime minister.     It is an unusual line in a country where politicians do not customarily talk about God or their religious beliefs, where church attendance is plummeting and same-sex marriage has become legal and widely accepted despite the opposition of many religious leaders.

headline: Deal Takes Capital One to New Turf
abstract: With its $14.6 billion acquisition of the North Fork Bancorporation, Capital One is looking less like a credit card company and more like a traditional bank. But will Wall Street approve?     For years, the success of Capital One, the country's largest stand-alone credit card issuer, rested on its uncanny ability to innovate, from new products (like zero-interest balance transfers) to new marketing (like a series of clever Viking ads).

headline: Mexico's Former Ruling Party Stumbles on the Road Back to Power
abstract: Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) is deeply divided after internal fight for presidential nomination; chosen candidate Roberto Madrazo's public image is so bad that he has stopped using his last name on campaign posters; party insiders charge that his relentless pursuit of nomination has left trail of wreckage; hold that no-holds-barred party boss lacks charisma to appeal to voters; photo; map (M)

headline: Microsoft Profit Rises 5%, Meeting Analysts' Forecasts
abstract: Microsoft said on Thursday that its quarterly profit rose 5 percent, matching Wall Street's forecasts, as the high cost of introducing the Xbox 360 game console was offset by strong sales of servers and software tools.     The company said net income was $3.65 billion, or 34 cents a share, for the three months ended Dec. 31, a period that included 1 cent a share in tax benefits. That compares with net income of $3.46 billion, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Chirac May Step In to Try to Resolve Crisis Over Jobs Law
abstract: President Jacques Chirac announced Wednesday that he would address the nation ''in the coming days,'' in a deepening political crisis over the government's standoff with students and unions over a new jobs law.     On Tuesday, huge protests in Paris turned violent, and the five major unions have called for another day of strikes and protests next Tuesday. Union leaders want Mr. Chirac to withdraw the law and send it back to Parliament for a new debate.

headline: Afghan Convert to Christianity Is Released, Officials Say
abstract: Afghan justice minister says Abdul Rahman, who faced death penalty for abandoning Islam and converting to Christianity, has been released from jail to his family; UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan say Rahman has asked for asylum outside Afghanistan; Islamic preachers used prayer services to call for Rahman's execution (M)

headline: Online trading alters Japan's playing field
Costs of war and storms take toll on U.S. budget
Managing Globalization: Costs of exporting labor
Black and White, All Over Again
abstract: It was a film about Truman Capote the writer that got the recent Oscar attention. But last week it was the turn of Truman Capote the party-giver.

headline: Examiner Is Sought in Refco Bankruptcy
abstract: Justice Department asks federal judge to appoint examiner to investigate whether Refco executives engaged in fraud or mismanagement before company's October bankruptcy filing (S)

headline: 3 More Die in Pakistan Cartoon Protests
abstract: Violent protests against the cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad grew, bringing the two-day death total to five.

headline: Aging bull: Plazas struggle
Trade Deficit Will Only Decline With the Economy
abstract: TWO decades ago, at a street fair called the Flatbush Frolic, I met the young congressman who represented the Brooklyn district to which I had recently moved. Few others seemed interested in talking to him, and we chatted for a few minutes.     One of the things he told me has stuck with me all these years. He said he had been the only congressman from New York City to vote against a union-backed piece of protectionist legislation aimed at stemming imports of cheap clothes.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Eni Sees Gas Crisis If Cold Weather Continues
abstract: Italy's gas shortages will reach crisis levels if cold temperatures persist, reducing strategic reserves to historically low levels, the head of Italy's biggest gas and oil company, Eni, said. Another 15 days of cold weather will turn Italy's gas situation into a ''red alert,'' Eni's chief executive, Paolo Scaroni, told journalists from Il Messaggero, which published his comments yesterday. Gianni di Giovanni, a company spokesman, confirmed the remarks. Eni, based in Rome, said almost 4 percent of the gas it requested in January from Gazprom of Russia was not delivered.

headline: A Path to a Seat on the Board? Try the Fairway
abstract: Corporations are under pressure to appoint experienced and independent board members, but golf handicaps and club memberships still play role; two of directors named to Morgan Stanley's board last summer are members of chmn John J Mack's own club, Golf Club of Purchase in Westchester County, as are two of his recent appointees to investment bank's management committee; most chief executives of large Wall Street banks belong to at least one major golf club, but according to tournament scores filed on Web site of US Golf Association, it appears that none of pure investment banks have more than one member of same club on their boards; photo (M)

headline: Abbas offers to resign if his program stalls
There Is No Place Like Home
abstract: WHAT was lost in all the frothy discussion last year about soaring real estate prices was just how much the homes themselves have changed.     The average home has increased 39 percent in size since 1974, and it has grown taller as well, according to the current issue of House & Garden.

headline: Blog Tracking Services Agree to Join Forces
abstract: Blog Tracking Services.

headline: Pakistanis Say U.S. Raid Left 4 or 5 Militants Dead
abstract: The provincial government said Tuesday that in addition to 18 civilians, four or five foreign militants were killed by the American airstrikes on the village of Damadola on Friday, but that their bodies were removed from the scene by companions. In all, 10 to 12 militants had been invited to a dinner in the village that night, it said.      The findings, the first official statement that militants had been among those killed, were from a preliminary joint investigation at the scene by government agencies.

headline: Parliament in Ukraine Votes to Scold Government
abstract: The Ukrainian Parliament passed a vote of no confidence in the government on Tuesday for its handling of negotiations in a dispute with Russia over the price of natural gas, but officials quickly dismissed the vote as a publicity stunt by the opposition.     President Viktor A. Yushchenko, who refused to cut short a trip to Kazakhstan, said that the current government would stay in place until parliamentary elections, which are scheduled for March 26, and that the gas deal would not be modified.

headline: EU places 92 foreign air carriers on blacklist
Violent clashes between Pakistani troops and militants
Hamas Is Silent on Leaders as the Power Tilts to Gaza
abstract: In an interview a few years ago, Mahmoud Zahar, a surgeon and senior leader of the radical Islamic movement Hamas, was asked his medical specialty.      ''Thyroids: I'm very good at cutting throats,'' Dr. Zahar said, drawing his forefinger across his neck as a rare smile spread across his face.

headline: Enron Figures Tell How Results Were Manipulated
abstract: Wesley H Colwell, former chief accountant of Enron's wholesale energy-trading unit, and Wanda Curry, former internal accountant, testify at trial of Kenneth L Lay and Jeffrey K Skilling; say company padded earnings and shifted hundreds of millions in losses from one division to another to disguise problems that might have concerned investors; testimony could be important in prosecution efforts to show that Skilling knowingly directed manipulations of Enron earnings and financial results and then lied about Enron's performance; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,270 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    EDWARDS, Amos C. Jr., 41, Sgt. First Class, Army National Guard; Savannah, Ga.; First Battalion, 118th Field Artillery, 48th Brigade Combat Team.    GARCIA, Anthony R., 48, Capt., Army; Fort Worth; 101st Airborne Division.

headline: Top Iraqi Leaders Agree to Form a Policy Council
abstract: Iraqi officials announced Sunday that they had agreed to form a council of the country's top politicians to make policy on security and economic issues in the new government. The council, which will include the prime minister and president, is an attempt to include all the country's major factions in decision making at a time of rising sectarian tensions.     The Iraqi Constitution approved by voters last fall does not have language supporting the creation of such a council. The 19-member body will essentially concentrate power in the hands of the country's political party leaders, and supersede the cabinet and Parliament in making broad decisions.

headline: A New Landscape: Hamas Digs In
abstract: When the radical Islamic group Hamas presented a cabinet it dominates to the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday, Yossi Alpher was reminded of an earlier revolution.     Mr. Alpher was an Israeli intelligence analyst on Iran from 1978 to 1980, and for him, the Hamas victory has the paradigm-shifting quality of the Iranian revolution that brought the mullahs of Shiite Islam to power. Today, he recognizes the same kind of dislocation.

headline: OPEC Said to Reject Iran's Bid to Cut Output
abstract: OPEC, rejecting calls from Iran and Venezuela to pare production, reportedly agrees to maintain current policy and keep pumping oil at 25-year record levels; OPEC president Edmund Daukoru says decision, if formally adopted, would mean production would be kept at early 1980's level in order to help build commercial stocks and keep 'ample' supplies on markets (M)

headline: New Bid for Guidant Sets Up a Showdown
abstract: After poring over Guidant's confidential financial records for more than a month, Boston Scientific said yesterday that it would make a formal, binding bid for the company that is worth $25 billion in cash and stock.     The offer is expected to set off a takeover battle between Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson, which had already agreed to buy Guidant for $21.4 billion. Johnson & Johnson lowered its earlier $25.4 billion offer because it said a raft of safety problems had diminished Guidant's value.

headline: Europe to get warning on energy use
Kadima offers West Bank scenario
Vietnamese court convicts Gary Glitter of abuse
Nikon Plans to Stop Making Most Cameras That Use Film
abstract: The Nikon Corporation, the Japanese camera maker, said Thursday that it would stop making most of its film cameras and lenses in order to focus on digital cameras.      The company, based in Tokyo, is the latest to join an industrywide shift toward digital photography, which has exploded in popularity. Rivals like Kodak and Canon have already shifted most of their camera production into digital products.

headline: Wireless: A way to pay by cellphone
All work / all play: Personal assistance for 'really big lives'
Corporate Boards Call on the Expertise of Retired Executives
abstract: The last thing Martin Coyne II wanted to do after taking early retirement in 2003 from his job as executive vice president of the Kodak Corporation's photography division was to return to the 12-hour days and the stress of the corporate world. Yet, he was only 55, and he yearned to put his management expertise to good use without wearing himself out.     So he chose an increasingly popular alternative: a career as a professional corporate director at small or medium-size companies.

headline: Dubai Will Delay Another Acquisition Involving U.S. Plants
abstract: Government-owned Dubai International Capital will delay $1.2 billion acquisition of British military equipment maker Doncasters Group from Royal Bank of Scotland Group due to American security concerns; Doncasters owns nine plants in United States which account for 40 percent of sales (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,282 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    DAVILA, Jessie, 29, Sgt., Army National Guard; Greensburg, Kan.; Second Battalion, 137th Infantry.    HOWARD, Curtis T. II, 32, Staff Sgt., Army; Ann Arbor, Mich.; Fourth Infantry Division.    MISNER, Gordon F. II, 23, Sgt., Army; Sparks, Nev.; Fourth Infantry Division.    VANALSTINE, Adam J., 21, Lance Cpl., Marines; Superior, Wis.; First Marine Division.    WILWERTH, Thomas J., 21, Specialist, Army; Mastic, N.Y.; Fourth Infantry Division.

headline: Dow Jones Names Successor to Its Chief Executive
abstract: The choice of Richard Zannino bypassed the current chief's candidate - his wife, who is leaving the company.

headline: Top UN powers meet to discuss Iran plan
Turkish teenager, who tested positive for bird flu, dies
Protection From Viruses and Spies, and Also Butterfingers
abstract: Laplink Software introduces PCdefense computer software and backup protection program; photo (S)

headline: French Law Is Affirmed as Protests Snarl Traffic
abstract: France's Constitutional Council upheld the constitutionality of a fiercely contested new labor law on Thursday, dealing a blow to opposition Socialists who had asked the council to strike it down but extending the crisis now facing the government.     Students kept up pressure, blocking roads and railways, tying up traffic and halting train service in several cities. The country's influential union syndicates have promised another day of nationwide strikes and protest marches on Tuesday.

headline: Pension Agency Hires Deutsche Bank to Sell 10% of UAL
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp hires Deutsche Bank to sell 10 percent stake in UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, in effort to raise more than $500 million; UAL is expected to exit from bankruptcy on February 1 (M)

headline: Tiny Jets May Usher in New Era, F.A.A. Says
abstract: Jets seating four to six passengers will soon open new travel opportunities at small airports, the agency said.

headline: Nike chief quits amid differences with founder
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Retail Sales Rose 2.3 Percent Last Month, Showing Promise of a Strong 2006 Economy  Shaking off a middling holiday shopping season and fears of higher heating bills, Americans spent freely in January as retail spending rose 2.3 percent in the month, up from 0.4 percent in December. The report provided reassurance that the economy is beginning the year with fresh strength. [Page A1.]    Drug That Helps Treat Cancer Has a High Price  Doctors are excited about the prospect of Avastin, a drug already widely used for colon cancer, as a new treatment for breast and lung cancer, too. But doctors are cringing at the price the maker, Genentech, plans to charge for it: about $100,000 a year. [A1.]    Asbestos Measure All but Dead in the Senate  The Senate decided to all but kill legislation to create a $140 billion fund to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning. [C1.]    Ovitz to Testify in Hollywood Wiretapping Inquiry  Michael Ovitz, the former Hollywood power player, has been called before a grand jury to testify about his dealings and conversations with Anthony Pellicano, the private detective who was indicted on wiretapping charges. [C1.]    Warren Buffett to Leave Board of Coca-Cola  The Coca-Cola Company, the largest soft-drink maker, said that Warren E. Buffett, its largest shareholder, left. would leave the board after 17 years. Mr. Buffett wants to spend more time managing Berkshire Hathaway, Coca-Cola said. Berkshire Hathaway holds an 8.4 percent stake worth $8 billion and will remain a shareholder. Mr. Buffett joined the board in 1989 and his term expires on April 19. [C8.]    Ahead of the Call for Alternative Energy Growth  General Electric, Goldman Sachs and J.P. Morgan Chase were all among companies making investments in alternative energy sources even before President Bush called last month for more effort in the industry. [C1.]    A Son Sues to Divide Sumner Redstone's Empire  The son of Sumner Redstone, the media mogul who controls CBS and Viacom, has filed a lawsuit to force a break up his father's empire, charging that he has not been treated fairly and his sister is being favored. [C1.]    Inquiry at Deutsche Bank Over Tax Shelters  Bank Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are investigating Deutsche Bank over its role in questionable tax shelters that helped wealthy investors evade billions of dollars in taxes, according to people briefed on the case. [C1.]    Details of Internet Restrictions in China Emerging  For Internet companies doing business in China, a piece of a booming market has not come without compromises. A series of episodes showing that the companies were bending to the restrictive demands of Beijing has leaked out from users inside China. [C3.]    A dozen former Communist Party officials and senior scholars have denounced the recent closing of a prominent news journal, helping to fuel a growing backlash against censorship. [A1.]    Two Central Bank Nominees Support Inflation Control  The nominees for the Federal Reserve, Randall S. Kroszner and Kevin M. Warsh, said in testimony to a Senate committee that controlling inflation was the best way to keep the economy growing and creating jobs. [C3.]    Exemptions From Oil Royalties Are Criticized  Democratic lawmakers and the White House said yesterday that oil and gas companies should not receive lucrative incentives when energy prices are near record highs. [C4.]    Warner Music's Profit Rises but Sales Miss Target  The Warner Music Group reported that its quarterly profit almost doubled in part because of strong sales of digital songs and lower costs, but revenue missed market expectations and its shares fell. The company also said it had received another subpoena in February from the New York State attorney general's office in connection with an antitrust investigation into the pricing of digital music downloads. [C15.]    Skilling Accused in Testimony of Lying About Enron  Jeffrey K. Skilling repeatedly lied about the true state of Enron's broadband Internet business and refused to lower earnings targets, even when it became clear that the business lacked customers and deals that could generate revenue, the former head of the company's broadband unit testified. [C3.]    Stocks Gain on Robust Retail Sales Report  Stocks gained as oil fell below $60 a barrel and January retail sales surpassed forecasts. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 136.07 points, to 11,028.39. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 12.67 points, or 1 percent, to 1,275.53. The Nasdaq composite index increased 22.36 points, to 2,262.17. [C9.]

headline: After Much Negotiation, Milosevic Will Be Buried in Serbia
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic's wife is expected to attend the funeral in Belgrade, although it was unclear whether the Serbian government would take legal action against her.

headline: Fed Panel Raises Rate to 4.75%
abstract: At Ben S. Bernanke's first meeting as head of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, the watchword was no surprises.     As expected, the Federal Open Market Committee raised the benchmark federal funds rate on Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.75 percent, and suggested that at least one more increase was in the cards. It was the 15th such increase in consecutive meetings of the committee.

headline: New Palestinian Parliament opens
Kiev murder trial delayed
Suit by A.I.G. Adds to the Rancor of Breaking Up Old Ties
abstract: A messy corporate divorce between American International Group and C. V. Starr & Company, a private insurer run by Maurice R. Greenberg, A.I.G.'s former chairman and chief executive, just got messier.      C. V. Starr, which operates four brokerage agencies and previously acted as a long-term compensation vehicle for past and present A.I.G. employees, is expanding the insurance it offers beyond A.I.G. The coverage will come from, among others, Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, and Ace Ltd., a company headed by Mr. Greenberg's son, Evan Greenberg.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,308 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    GONZALEZ, Carlos M., 22, Specialist, Army; Middletown, N.Y.; 101st Airborne Division.    PINSON, Amanda N., 21, Sgt., Army; St. Louis; 101st Airborne Division.

headline: As Bird Flu Spreads, Officials Shift to Vaccination Campaigns
abstract: Vaccination campaigns are so far employed only in a few parts of Asia with deeply entrenched bird flu problems.

headline: High Profits, Sluggish Investments
abstract: AS oil company earnings soar, there is talk of excess profits and a new windfall profits tax. The real issue, though, is not how much the oil companies are making, but what they are doing with the money. In too many cases, they seem to have only a limited interest in investing it in projects that might help prevent or ameliorate a new energy crisis.     Exxon Mobil, the world's most valuable company, reported this week that it earned $36 billion in 2005. But it was only able to find ways to invest less than half that amount. Instead, Exxon Mobil's chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, bragged that it had distributed $23.2 billion to shareholders, ''an increase of 56 percent, or $8.3 billion, from 2004.''

headline: Election Role Won't Soften Hamas Anger at the Israelis
abstract: Hamas's most prominent leader in Gaza and the West Bank, Mahmoud Zahar, said Wednesday that his faction would still refuse to recognize Israel or disarm even if it won in the Palestinian elections this month.      ''The calmness has ended,'' Mr. Zahar said, referring to the truce under which Palestinians agreed not to attack Israel through 2005. But he left open the possibility that Hamas might refrain from attacks on Israel ''if not provoked.''

headline: North says return to talks 'impossible' unless U.S. lifts sanctions
Iraqi Insurgents Attack Jail, Killing 18 and Freeing Prisoners
abstract: More than 200 masked insurgents stormed an Interior Ministry jail at daybreak on Tuesday, killing at least 18 police officers, freeing all the prisoners and leaving the facility a smoldering wreck.      The battle raged for nearly an hour at the jail, in Muqdadiya, 60 miles northeast of Baghdad, as the fighters blasted government buildings with mortars, grenades and machine guns, Interior Ministry officials said.

headline: Oil prices jump after attacks sharply curb Nigerian output
Text: ETA's statement
17 Iraqi police officers killed in attack
Crowds Demand Resignation of Thai Leader
abstract: Opponents of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand organized a huge demonstration in Bangkok on Saturday that stretched into the early hours Sunday, and a second cabinet minister resigned as criticism mounted over Mr. Thaksin's recent business deals.     Newspapers and opposition politicians have expressed outrage that Mr. Thaksin, one of the wealthiest men in Southeast Asia, sold nearly $2 billion worth of assets -- including stock holdings in satellite, telecommunications and news media concerns -- without paying any tax.

headline: British Muslim cleric's trial opens with accusation of racial hatred
The End User: Finding video made easy
Those Bell Mergers Are Giving Cable Companies Even More to Worry About
abstract: In the chess game between the cable companies and their nemeses, the Bell phone companies, the Bells may be gaining ground. Phone mergers -- including AT&T's recent proposal to take over BellSouth -- could give the Bells more power to cut prices, move faster into television and expand their advantage in the wireless market.     Sheer size also helps the Bells throw their weight around in Washington. Last week, lawmakers began drafting a bill to make it easier for the Bell companies to acquire local television franchises, a move that would help speed up their push to sell TV programming over high-speed lines around the country.

headline: Gazprom's interests are hard to differentiate from those of Russia
U.S. poultry industry braces for action
Ex-Raytheon Chief Agrees to Fine and Forfeit of Part of Bonus
abstract: Former Raytheon chief executive Daniel Burnham, neither admitting nor denying Securities and Exchange Commission charges of accounting irregularities in 2000 and 2001, agrees to pay fine and return part of $1.75 million bonus; photo (M)

headline: Iran Earthquake Kills 70, Destroys 330 Villages
abstract: The number of deaths might not rise much higher, since most residents in the province were roused by a weaker earthquake a few hours earlier.

headline: Wanted: Alternative to Hillary Clinton
Official Washington Pays Tribute to Reporter Who Was Killed
abstract: More than 700 people, from members of Congress and journalists to friends and relatives from around the country, packed into a Senate office building here on Friday to honor David E. Rosenbaum, a retired New York Times reporter who died after being assaulted near his Washington home.      Mr. Rosenbaum, 63, who was known for untangling the intricacies of government with clarity and fairness over a 37-year career, was remembered as a modest, unpretentious man devoted first to his family and then to his profession.

headline: Long on Outskirts of Power, Olmert Looks to Lead Israel
abstract: Israeli leader Ehud Olmert hopes to win national election in his own right after years as behind-scenes political figure who fashioned new centrist Kadima party with Ariel Sharon and helped develop Sharon's policy of unilateral withdrawal from Palestinians areas; Kadima was built around Sharon but Olmert has steered it through difficult period, enforcing party discipline, limiting own public role and appointing popular Tzipi Livni as deputy; photo (M)

headline: In broadband, big gains by small firms
Top Indonesian Generals Take Control of Restive City
abstract: Indonesia's top military and police officials take control of Jayapura in Papua, ordering arrest of university students and directing police to fire into air as they patrol streets; nearly 60 people have been arrested after violent demonstration on March 16; protest was directed at American mining company Freeport-McMoRan, which operates gold and copper mine in province; company pays individual police and military officers to protect its mining operations (M)

headline: Top U.S. Commander Warns of Dangers for New Iraqi Government
abstract: Lt. Gen. John R. Vines has offered a sober assessment of the hurdles facing a new Iraqi government.

headline: Questions Raised About Sharon's Prospects for Recovery
abstract: Israeli media has been debating the treatment he received between his first stroke in December and his second one in January.

headline: Opening the Door on the Credit Report and Throwing Away the Lock
abstract: Your Money column on credit-reporting agencies that are pushing Congress to override state laws that set up procedures for residents of identity theft to lock and unlock their credit reports; says overriding laws could make it harder for Americans to keep their credit information under wraps; holds lobbyists for big agencies--Equifax, Experian and TransUnion, owned by Marmon Group--are seeking to add amendment to Financial Data Protection Act; contends that those few people who have been victimized by identity thieves, not credit-card thieves, and continue to be vulnerable should take extra precautions; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Relic To Be Razed
abstract: Parliament rejected a last-minute attempt to save what is left of the Palace of the Republic in Berlin, the home of the East German Parliament, and demolition is now expected to begin next month. The fate of the building -- a huge steel-and-concrete complex with bronze-colored windows that opened in 1976 and also housed a concert hall -- has divided Berliners for more than a decade. After German reunification in 1990, the building was closed, and it was gutted after asbestos contamination was discovered.   VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

headline: Heart Drug Maker Will Lay Off 150
abstract: Scios unit of Johnson & Johnson will lay off 150 of its 900 workers; division has struggled with sales of heart failure treatment Natrecor after concerns over safety; Scios is under investigation by Justice Department on whether it improperly promoted Natrecor for unapproved use; drug is meant to treat acute heart failure but has also been widely used for less severe heart failure; doctors are allowed to prescribe drugs as they choose but drug companies cannot promote off-label use; Scios denies any wrongdoing (M)

headline: Pope's Freed Attacker Does Not Check in With Turkish Police
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca, who tried to kill Pope John Paul II, has not made required daily check-ins with Istanbul police since his release from Turkish prison on Jan 12; was required to report until doctors determined that he was fit enough for mandatory military service, but his lawyer says Agca applied years ago to make payments in place of military service; such a practice is legal for Turks with long-term residence outside country; Agca was in prison in Italy for 19 years (M)

headline: Executive attacks enemies with 'Locusts'
Ex-Bush aide disputes late Katrina warning
British historian pleads guilty in Holocaust trial
Militants smash border wall in Gaza
G.M. Will Cut Executive Pay and Dividend
abstract: General Motors, under pressure to show its blue-collar workers that investors and executives are also prepared to give up something in order to help overcome the company's deepest losses in more than a decade, said Tuesday that it would reduce pay for top officials and cut its stock dividend by half.     G.M., still clinging to its status as the world's largest auto company, also announced changes in the pension and health care plans for its retired salaried workers as it struggles to turn around its operations and avoid a potential bankruptcy.

headline: Controversial comments by Agca after pope's shooting
New ideas to ease into old age
Pilots Demand $1 Billion if Delta Ends Pensions
abstract: Air Lines Pilots Assn is demanding $1 billion payment if Delta Air Lines ends pension benefits as part of bankruptcy reorganization; airline has offered $300 million; Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp says Delta's pension programs are underfunded by $10.6 billion; Northwest Airlines' Pilots union will vote this month on allowing union leaders to call strike if company rejects contract in bankruptcy court; Northwest is seeking permission to end contract and impose new terms; Northwest says it needs to cut annual expenses by $2.5 billion (M)

headline: Bolivia Indians Hail the Swearing In of One of Their Own as President
abstract: Evo Morales, a Socialist protest leader and steadfast critic of American policies in the region, was sworn in Sunday as president of Bolivia, the first Indian to hold the position in this landlocked country whose indigenous majority had long felt oppressed and cut off from political power.     With tears welling in his eyes, his left fist raised and his right hand over his heart, Mr. Morales, 46, an Aymara Indian, took the oath of office as the leaders of 11 countries, American diplomats and the crown prince of Spain watched from the gallery of the country's ornate 19th-century Congress.

abstract: Advertising agencies and their parent companies are increasing online investments in what is known as search marketing; category has estimated worth of $5.1 billion last year with spending expected to reach $6.5 billion this year; niche is growing faster than traditional advertising in other media; agencies are providing services to prevent clients from using independent specialists; early problems such as click fraud are being addressed as industry matures; photo (M)

headline: 3 EU nations want Iran taken to UN
2 Gas Companies to Merge
abstract: Linde agrees to buy BOC Group of Britain for 8 billion pounds ($14 billion), to become biggest maker of industrial gases used in factories, oil refineries and hospital operating rooms (S)

headline: Starbucks wins trademark dispute
Iraqi Security Forces Prepare for Shiite Holy Day
abstract: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 5 Â Five Iraqis were killed in scattered violence across Iraq today, as thousands of Iraqi soldiers and police officers began to move into place to protect Shiite pilgrims for a religious holiday this week.

headline: China Seeking Auto Industry, Piece by Piece
abstract: China is pursuing a novel way to catapult its automaking into a global force: buy one of the world's most sophisticated engine plants, take it apart, piece by piece, transport it halfway around the globe and put it back together again at home.      In the latest sign of this country's manufacturing ambitions, a major Chinese company, hand-in-hand with the Communist Party, is bidding to buy from DaimlerChrysler and BMW a car engine plant in Brazil.

headline: Officials appeal for solution to nuclear dispute
Europe, Asia, Africa
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Consolidation is expected to follow
Volkswagen Chairman Will Step Down
abstract: A high-stakes boardroom battle at Volkswagen ended in a truce Friday, as Ferdinand K. Piëch, the company's chairman and an heir to the Porsche fortune, agreed to step down next year in return for two Porsche executives gaining seats on the board.     Mr. Piëch, a powerful figure who was once Volkswagen's chief executive, has been accused by shareholders and other board members of a conflict of interest since Porsche, the sports car maker controlled by his family, acquired 18.5 percent of Volkswagen's shares last fall.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Toyota Shuts Factory Amid Strike
abstract: Toyota Motor indefinitely shut its factory in a suburb of Bangalore after a strike over the firing of three employees. Nearly 1,600 workers at the factory, which is run by Toyota Kirloskar Auto Parts, went on strike Friday to demand that the three be reinstated. The company said the employees were fired for violating the company's code of conduct. The company, a joint venture of Toyota and the Kirloskar group of India, is 89 percent owned by Toyota and makes the Corolla and Innova models. A company spokesman was quoted in wire service reports as saying the lockout was done to ensure the safety of executives and the plant. Talks between workers and company management are scheduled for this week.    SARITHA RAI (NYT)

headline: In Defense of Soda and Gum
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Cadbury Schweppes chief executive Tod Stitzer, who comments on company's future in beverage business in US and possible reasons why people are chewing more gum; photo (M)

abstract: Roundup of past week's stock market results; graphs (M)

headline: THE CHURN
abstract: People       Mark Rufeh is joining Credit Suisse as a managing director and head of strategy implementation and expense management. Mr. Rufeh joins Credit Suisse from the Westchester Capital Group, a real estate private equity firm. Previously, he was at Lehman Brothers.     Pimco has announced three hires.  Richard H. Clarida, a former assistant secretary of the Treasury for economic policy, has joined as an executive vice president and global strategic adviser. Andrew Balls will join as a senior vice president and global strategist in June. He is currently a correspondent with The Financial Times.  Edward J. Devlin is joining from Lehman Brothers' London office to become a senior vice president and portfolio manager.

headline: British law course Shanghaied?

When the Market Values Hope Over Experience by a Factor of 18
abstract: THREE companies with household names are worth about the same amount now -- at least in the opinion of investors. Google, I.B.M. and Berkshire Hathaway all have market capitalizations in the vicinity of $135 billion.     But if they are equal in value, they are very different in what an investor got for his or her money this week, as is shown in the accompanying charts, which are based on Friday's closing prices.

headline: Playboy Makes Move in India, but Without the Centerfold
abstract: In a little-noticed milestone for the world of sex-related entertainment, Playboy said last month that it would seek to do in India what it had never done before: publish a magazine with its usual fare, except for its name and its nudes.      ''This is quite a departure for us,'' Christie Hefner, the chief executive of Playboy Enterprises, told reporters in December.

headline: Iraqi Official Says Foreign Forces Could Fall Below 100,000 This Year
abstract: The chairman of a high-level group planning the transfer of security responsibilities from American to Iraqi troops said the number of American and other foreign soldiers here would probably fall to below 100,000 by year's end and that an overwhelming majority could be out in two years.     The statements by Mowaffak al-Rubaie, Iraq's national security adviser and the chairman of a joint Iraqi-American committee planning the transfer, give the strongest indication yet that the Bush administration is preparing to carry out significant reductions in American forces over the current year.

headline: At coal mine, initial joy turns to tears
Airlines banned or restricted
Carlsberg closing its home brewery
TechBrief: Microsoft reply to EU is posted on Internet
Sporting News Settles Case on Gambling Ads
abstract: The Sporting News, one of the nation's oldest sports-centered media companies, has entered into a $7.2 million settlement to resolve accusations that it promoted Internet gambling by publishing and broadcasting advertisements for online casinos overseas, the Department of Justice said yesterday.     Under the settlement, The Sporting News, which is operated by Vulcan Sports Media, a company owned by the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen, has agreed to pay a $4.2 million fine. It will also complete a three-year public service campaign, valued at $3 million, to educate people about illegal Internet and telephone gambling.

headline: Soldier's death in Iraq is Britain's 100th
Mergers Rise and Analysts Take Notice
abstract: LOVE is in the air in corporate boardrooms, or is it just the realization that it can hurt to be alone?     Businesses have been pursuing mergers and acquisitions more vigorously than at any time since the tech boom of the late 1990's; $2.7 trillion worth of deals were reached worldwide last year, 38.4 percent more than in 2004, according to Thomson Financial. The research firm expects another big year, and the first couple of weeks have been marked by announcements of several deals, speculation about others and the emergence of a bidding war for Guidant between Boston Scientific and Johnson & Johnson.

headline: In Belarus village, tradition gets vote
Swedes step ahead on ethnic harmony
Objections to port deal dismissed
Rubens and Rembrandt, a Day's Loot for Balkan Gangs
abstract: Thieves robbed Novi Sad City Museum in Serbia in January, tying up unarmed night watchman and museum guide and stealing four works, including one by Rubens and another by Rembrandt; same Rembrandt was stolen in 1993, but recovered nine months later; museum's security system was never improved after first theft; Art Loss register says Balkan gangs have established reputation for art theft in Western Europe; photos; map (M)

headline: Joint Venture Is Doubled
abstract: Jefferies Group and MassMutual Financial Group plan to double their stakes in Jefferies Babson Finance, joint venture that finances buyouts and corporate loans, bringing total investment to $500 million; Jefferies reports fourth quarter net income rose 32 percent, to $46.7 million, and investment banking revenue surged 58 percent(S)

headline: Georgia's gas flow partly restored
Suspect's smiles shock French after slaying
Amnesty denounces Iraq prison abuse
Japanese Remarks About Taiwan Anger Beijing
abstract: The quarrel between Tokyo and Beijing over Japan's colonial and wartime history spilled over to the sensitive topic of Taiwan over the weekend, after Japan's foreign minister praised his country's past rule over the island.     The minister, Taro Aso, said in a speech on Saturday that Taiwan's present high educational standards resulted from Japanese colonial policies. China, which ceded Taiwan after losing a war to Japan in 1895 and considers the island a renegade province, condemned the comments on Sunday.

headline: Ex-Wal-Mart executive pleads guilty to fraud
Merkel lays out foreign policy, emphasizing 'values'
Former Refco Chief Resigns From Board
abstract: Phillip Bennett, the former chief executive of Refco, resigned from the firm's board yesterday after a federal bankruptcy judge directed Refco to replace its board members.      Judge Robert Drain of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York had said he would appoint a trustee to run the company unless Refco replaced its board members.

Back of the Envelope
abstract: Financing has been cheap, even as the Federal Reserve has been steadily pushing up interest rates since July 2004, and that has helped fuel the boom in mergers. Fed policy makers are widely expected to raise rates another quarter-point next week.

headline: In 2005, Companies Set a Record for Sharing With Shareholders
abstract: AMERICAN companies have plenty of cash, and they are sharing it with their owners.     Companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index paid a record $202 billion in dividends last year, up 11 percent from 2004.
